questions.question: We started early in the morning so that we ……………………… not get stuck in the traffic.
questions.description: Would, could and might are common after so that when the verb in the main clause is in the past tense.

questions.question: I had never before met so ………………………………
questions.description: In this special structure we use so + adjective + a/an + singular countable noun.

questions.question: I was angry and so ……………………… the others.
questions.description: The same auxiliary is used in both clauses in this structure.

questions.question: He spoke in a low voice …………………………. avoid waking up the baby.
questions.description: So as to means the same as in order to.

questions.question: I will call you when they …………………………….
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the future tense, we use a present tense in the subordinate clause to refer to future.

questions.question: They were watching TV when the burglars ………………………….. in
questions.description: We use the simple past for the short action that took place in the middle of the longer action.

questions.question: I usually drink coffee in the morning, but today I ……………………… tea.
questions.description: We use the simple past to say that something happened on a particular occasion in the past.

questions.question: James is one of the players who …………………………. been selected for the match.
questions.description: Here the subject is the plural noun players hence we use have.

questions.question: Each child ……………………………. given a prize.
questions.description: We use a singular verb after each.

questions.question: She has been to ……………………………… all continents.
…………………………… by the storm, we took shelter under a bridge.
questions.description: We were driven by the storm. We took shelter under a bridge. We can combine these two clauses using the past participle driven.
